Problem:
Consider the complex function \( z(t) = u(t) + iv(t) \) where \( u(t) \) and \( v(t) \) are real functions representing the real and imaginary parts, respectively. The function's evolution is governed by the linear differential equation \( \dot{z} = Pz \), where \( P \) is a constant complex matrix. We explore the effect of applying an integral transformation \( I(z) = \int_0^t e^{Qt}z(\tau) d\tau \), where \( Q \) is another constant complex matrix.

If \( I(z) \) is applied to \( z_0 \) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve under \( \dot{z} = Pz \) without further intervention, will \( z(t) \) at t = T be the same as if \( z_0 \) was directly evolved to t = T under \( \dot{z} = Pz \)?
Explanation: The application of \( I(z) \) changes the initial conditions by integrating the effect of \( e^{Qt}z(\tau) \) over time. This transformation alters the evolutionary path of \( z(t) \), producing a different outcome at time T due to the specific effects of matrix \( Q \).
